Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that Republicans passed laws making it legal to run over protesters with your car, when in reality, the proposed legislation did not become law.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence provided to support the assertion that Republicans passed such laws.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption that Republicans responded to the Charlottesville attack by passing laws to make it legal to run over protesters, when the proposed legislation predates the attack.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the proposed legislation did not become law, but the claim implies that it did.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation is that the proposed legislation aimed to provide some protections for drivers who unintentionally injure demonstrators blocking streets, rather than making it legal to intentionally run over protesters.
Understate: The claim may understate the context and timing of the proposed legislation, as it fails to mention that the bills were introduced prior to the Charlottesville attack and were not enacted.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by misrepresenting the proposed legislation as actual laws passed by Republicans.
